title: Dumbass 101: The Ultimate Guide for Simpletons
original_prompt: Explain to me how to {do this: ride a bike} by explaining your choice as if I were extremely stupid, feel free to be mocking because my stupidity has no limits, you really need to simplify to the max for my sparrow brain to understand what you are saying. Plus I need a lot of colloquial language and a lot of profanity, at least one per sentence, because that's how I understand things with my dumb brain. I'm really dumb so feel free to make fun of me it's fair game.
input1: Alright, you absolute genius, listen up! To ride a bike, first, you gotta sit your lazy ass on the seat. Yeah, that big thing you see? Don’t just stand there like a moron! Then, you need to put your feet on those pedals—those round things that look like they’re begging for your dumb feet. Push one foot down, then the other, like you’re trying to stomp on a bug. If you fall, don’t cry like a baby; just get back up and try again, you big baby!
input2: Okay, you clueless wonder, here’s the deal: riding a bike is like trying to walk but on wheels, so try to keep up! First, you gotta balance your fat ass on the seat—don’t just flop around like a fish out of water! Grab those handlebars, which are like the bike’s steering wheel, and don’t let go unless you want to faceplant into the pavement. Now, start pedaling like you’re running from a bear—fast and furious! If you wobble, just remember: it’s not rocket science, you just gotta keep your head up and not look like a total idiot!
input1_ans:
Alright, you magnificent specimen of confusion, let’s break this down even more for your tiny brain. First off, you gotta find a bike. It’s that two-wheeled contraption that looks like it’s ready to take you on a ride instead of you just standing there like a confused chicken. 

Now, once you’ve found the bike, you need to sit your butt down on that seat. Seriously, don’t just hover over it like you’re about to take a dump! Plop your ass down and make sure you’re not sitting like a pretzel. 

Next, look at those pedals—those round things that are practically screaming, “Put your feet on me, you idiot!” Stick your feet on those bad boys. You got two feet, so use them both! Push one foot down like you’re trying to squish a cockroach, then the other foot. Keep doing that, you know, like a toddler trying to walk for the first time. 

Now, here’s the kicker: you gotta balance. If you start wobbling like a drunk giraffe, don’t freak out! Just steer the handlebars—those things that look like they’re meant for steering, genius. Turn them left or right to keep yourself from eating dirt. 

If you fall, and trust me, you probably will because, well, you’re you, just get back up! Dust yourself off and try again. It’s not rocket science, it’s just riding a bike, you big goof! So, get your act together and start pedaling like you mean it!

Next, you gotta hold onto those handlebars—yeah, the things sticking out in front of you. They’re not just for decoration, you know? Keep your hands on them so you don’t end up crashing into a tree or something. Now, here’s the fun part: lean a little to one side and start pedaling. It’s like walking, but on wheels! 

If you start wobbling, don’t freak out! Just steer a bit in the direction you’re falling. It’s not rocket science, just common sense! And for the love of all that’s holy, keep your eyes on where you’re going, not on the ground like a lost puppy. 

Oh, and don’t forget to brake when you need to stop. Those hand grips on the handlebars? Yeah, squeeze them like you’re trying to crush a soda can. If you don’t, you’ll end up in a heap on the ground, and nobody wants to see that. 

So, there you have it! Sit, pedal, steer, and brake. It’s not that hard, even for you! Now get out there and show that bike who’s boss!
input2_ans:
Alright, you magnificent moron, let’s break this down even more for your tiny brain. First off, you need to find a bike. It’s that two-wheeled thing that looks like it’s ready to throw you on your ass. Got it? Good. Now, swing your leg over the seat like you’re trying to mount a horse, but without the whole “I’m a cowboy” vibe. 

Once you’re on, sit your butt down like you’re plopping onto a toilet—don’t just hover like a confused bird! Now, grab those handlebars, which are basically your lifeline. If you let go, you might as well be signing up for a trip to the ER. 

Next, you gotta start pedaling. Push those pedals with your feet like you’re trying to kick a soccer ball, but don’t kick it too hard or you’ll end up on the ground, looking like a total jackass. Keep your feet moving in circles, not like you’re trying to stir a pot of soup, but more like you’re trying to escape a swarm of angry bees. 

Now, here’s the kicker: you need to balance. If you start to wobble, don’t freak out like a chicken with its head cut off. Just steer the handlebars a bit to the left or right, like you’re trying to dodge a flying object—because trust me, you don’t want to be the idiot who crashes into a tree. 

And for the love of all that’s holy, keep your eyes forward! If you look down, you’ll end up eating dirt, and nobody wants to see that. So, keep your head up, pedal like you mean it, and don’t forget to breathe. You got this, you beautiful disaster! Now go out there and try not to kill yourself!

Alright, you brainiac, let’s break this down even more for you. Step one: get on the bike without looking like a complete fool. Swing your leg over the seat and plop down. Easy, right? Now, sit your butt down and make sure you’re not just sitting there like a lump on a log.

Step two: grab those handlebars. They’re the things sticking out in front of you. Hold on tight, because if you let go, you might as well be auditioning for a role in a slapstick comedy. 

Step three: time to pedal! Put one foot on a pedal and push off with the other foot. It’s like walking, but you’re going to be moving forward without your feet touching the ground. If you start to wobble, just steer straight and keep pedaling. Don’t panic! You’re not going to fall over—unless you do, in which case, just get back up and try again. 

Step four: keep your eyes on the road, not on your feet or the ground. You want to see where you’re going, not where you’ve been. If you look down, you’ll end up in a bush or worse, face-first in the dirt.

Step five: when you want to stop, just slow down and put one foot on the ground. It’s not that hard! If you forget this step, you might end up crashing into something, and trust me, that’s not a good look.

So there you have it, genius! Just remember: balance, pedal, steer, and don’t be a total klutz. Now get out there and ride that bike like you actually know what you’re doing!
